ARTICLE.TITLE: New outbreak at Tyson Plant; program to help Iowa struggling farmers
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Starting this week, the Iowa Department of Agriculture launched the Disposable Assistance Program to provide financial resources to pork producers to properly dispose of animals. For this program, the state is allocating $24 million.

This is in addition to the USDA’s recently announced COVID-19 Food Assistance Program, which provides up to $16 billion in direct payments to American farmers.

Iowa Secretary of Agriculture Mike Naig says pork production has lost roughly 25 percent of its processing capacity, causing a backup of around 600,000 pigs in Iowa that would otherwise go to market.

According to the Iowa Department of Health, there were 15 new deaths, totaling 500 and 246 new cases of COVID-19, bringing the total number to 18,502 positive cases statewide. Health officials say there have been 142,321 total tested, with 13% positive and 123,397 negative.

The state is also reporting a total of 10,148 COVID-19 patient recoveries, which means 289 have recovered over the last 24-hours.

On average, 1 in 22 Iowans have been tested, 16,042 serology tests conducted, and 552,398 TestIowa assessments completed. There are currently 383 hospitalized due to COVID-19, with 30 admitted in the lasts 24 hours. 112 patients are in intensive care and 67 patients on ventilators.
